titleStmt.title: M112, Set 2 of 3 [The Reader: must in order to sit and stand there, while the sun beats...]. Typescript fragment, unsigned and undated with the author's ms. additions. 2 fols.
titleStmt.author: Virginia Woolf

publicationStmt.authority: The Estate of Virginia Woolf, administered by the Society of Authors

msIdentifier.repository: Henry W. and Albert A. Berg Collection of English and American Literature

physDesc.p: M112, Set 2 of 3 [The Reader: must in order to sit and stand there, while the sun beats...]. Typescript fragment, unsigned and undated with the author's ms. additions. 2 fols.

handNote.p: Holograph writing by the documents' main hand, Virginia Woolf

correction.p: Apparent errors have been explicitly corrected in sic / corr tags, wrapped in a choice element.

interpretation.p: Names and references to places and literary works have been wrapped in rs tags which link to annotations and secondary material.

projectDesc.p: Text encoded as part of 'The Digital "Anon": A Digital Genetic Edition of Virginia Woolf's Final Essays'. This project, funded by Leverhulme Grant ECF-2022-602, seeks to construct a TEI-XML based digital edition of the drafts of 'Anon' and 'The Reader', among the final documents Woolf wrote before her death.

div.p:
must in order to sit and stand there, while the sun beats or the rain pours have some strong inducement; something that puzzles; and then concludes. They must have love; murder; adultery. And this contrbution (contribution) of the audience was more unfortunate to the dramatist tahn (than) to the lyric singer. Often the actions is too violent for the words. There is a dislocation between the thought and the action. No one feels what is said. The emotion is often
las ered (plastered) on to a dumb figure. But if violence rapidity movement are dictated by the audience an inevitable confusin (confusion) follows. On the other hand the playwright like the singer has an anomymous vitality, drawn fro (from) other bodies, a pe renniel (perennial) common vigour. Nor is dad (dead) in ourselves. The crude early ddrams (dramas) have still the power to make us ask--as the audience asked-- the childs questin (question): what comes next? a power denied to [20th?] century [illeg.] So we become ourelves (ourselves) anonymous in the early plays.

It is only later when the pressure of silent horaded (hoarded) emotion had thrown up words, as the fi gers (fingers) of the man at the casts letters from the bubbling lead, that we lose this general quality to gain--- everything it seems. For the curatin (curtain) goes on rising incessantly for fifty years. Now it rises on ; then on ; on ; on ; finally on . Byt (By) that time the sxxgxx play has outgrown the stage. The stage has become too small to act this drama. Perhaps after cnuries (centuries), the play will come to birth again, differently, in , in . But the play never again fitted the stage
completely in England. The book after takes the place of the play. And Anon is dead for ever.
